Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: IMEE: Disaster Recovery, Social Capital, and the Sri Lankan Context: A Comparative Study of Two Communities in Batticaloa

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will analyze recovery processes and outcomes in two communities in Batticaloa, Sri Lanka: one predominantly Tamil/Hindu community and one Muslim community. This area suffered the impact of the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami and the civil war in Sri Lanka, and provides an opportunity to understand the interaction between complex humanitarian emergencies and natural disasters. Within a context of insurgencies and "small wars" around the world, increasing disaster losses, and global environmental change, both nations and the international communities are faced with the challenge of providing disaster assistance in the context of ongoing humanitarian crises. This research will result in practical lessons regarding disaster recovery in areas affected by armed conflict. It will also contribute fundamental knowledge to the efforts to build a theory of community recovery from disasters which should increase community resilience around the world.

The research focuses on three community-level recovery outcomes: social recovery; infrastructure and built-environment recovery; and the extent to which risk reduction measures have been incorporated into the recovery process. The study will investigate the impacts on recovery of three broad sets of factors: pre-existing conditions; disaster impacts; and post-disaster conditions and recovery-related interventions. Using the knowledge gained through earlier NSF-sponsored fieldwork, the co-PI will conduct exploratory and open-ended interviews with district and local leaders, live in each of the two study communities and participate in everyday community activities, and explore local recovery dynamics, with a specific emphasis on the ways in which recovery challenges were influenced by experiences in the civil war. In addition to community members, the co-PI will interview local, district, and national government officials and individuals involved with relevant relief and recovery projects, such as representatives of non-governmental organizations. The findings from this project will be integrated into University of Colorado undergraduate curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Utilizing a comparative case-study approach, this research seeks to inform our intellectual and practical understandings of the ways in which communities recover from disasters within the context of armed violence. Specifically, this project focuses on the ways in which two communities in rural eastern Sri Lanka recovered differently from the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami while embedded in the armed conflict of the Sri Lankan civil war (1983-2009). With the funding from this National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement grant, the co-PI was able to travel to Sri Lanka to conduct interviews with more than two hundred tsunami and war survivors along with various stakeholders in both government and non-governmental sectors. By conducting research in two communities: one majority Tamil/Hindu, and the other one hundred percent Muslim, this project seeks to clarify how we understand community-level variations in recovery, specifically as those variations relate to the dynamics of ethno-religious armed conflicts.

With the help of the co-PI’s Tamil translator and research assistant, interviews were conducted with: community members and leaders, local academics, folks who have worked on recovery-related social and infrastructure projects, local and district-level government officials, and leaders of community based organizations including those working with a prominent women’s rights organization and the mosque committee (in the Muslim village), and the rural development societies of both villages. Further, the co-PI had the opportunity to attend a tsunami practice drill in one village, which was enlightening for many reasons, including that she was able to meet with Sri Lankan army personnel who were conducting the drill. Attending the drill, and gaining access to government leaders through this exercise went beyond the scope of expected access to the field, and allows for a deeper analysis of local disaster management systems, and the dynamic interplay between civil and military forces.

Though data analysis is still underway, there are a number of significant results that have already been identified. First, in the context of war, a community’s ethno-religious affiliations matter. Though this may seem obvious at the outset, this research allows us to understand the most nuanced ways in which ethnicity, race, religion, and other axes of social differences contribute to the recovery processes and outcomes for communities. We have also been able to clarify the ways in which relief and recovery-aid tends to flow along political lines, and have some practical suggestions related to how this process may take place for a more effective and equitable distribution of aid to communities in need, especially in areas that may be marginalized during armed violence. It has also become abundantly clear that disaster recovery projects have become inseparable from larger “development” projects. As the current goal of community recovery is to “build back better” or “develop sustainably,” it has become increasingly important that these recovery projects be viewed from the perspective of participatory development. Specifically, we have found that successful infrastructure recovery requires input from affected communities and strong flows of communication between all stakeholders (governments, communities, and those entities involved in funding and implementing the projects). Furthermore, oversight of these projects is an imperative: the most successful projects were diligently monitored by both local and foreign aid workers and integrated community input throughout the recovery process.

The results of this project have already begun to be disseminated. In October 2016, the co-PI presented some preliminary findings at the 45th Annual Conference on South Asian Studies in Madison, Wisconsin. Additionally, the co-PI has integrated a number of lessons-learned into Sociology courses taught at the University of Colorado, Boulder. We also expect that these lessons will be integrated into curriculums in various departments across the university campus including Engineering, Environmental Studies, Anthropology, and Geography. Outside of the university system, this research has important applications for disaster practitioners world-wide. Within a context of insurgencies and “small wars” around the world, increasing disaster losses, and global environmental change, both nations and the international communities are faced with the challenge of providing disaster assistance in the context of ongoing humanitarian crises. This research aims to better-inform those practitioners and aid-workers as they engage in recovery-related projects in unfamiliar cultural contexts.
